results.title: Carrie-Anne Moss on the ‘Matrix’ Movies and Playing an Action Hero in Her 50s
results.abstract: The actress synonymous with Trinity faced the weight of expectations when she reunited with Keanu Reeves and Lana Wachowski for the new sequel.

multimedia.caption: Carrie-Anne Moss said she “let go of any construct in my mind that I needed to look like I did when I was 30” for the new sequel.
multimedia.copyright: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

results.title: ‘The Matrix Resurrections’ Review: Slipping Through Dreamland (Again)
results.abstract: Keanu Reeves plunges down the rabbit hole once more in this familiar-seeming mind-game movie, the fourth in the series.

multimedia.caption: Carrie-Anne Moss and Keanu Reeves in “The Matrix Resurrections.”

results.title: ‘Tragedy of Macbeth’ Review: The Thane, Insane, Slays Mainly in Dunsinane
results.abstract: Denzel Washington and Frances McDormand play a toxic power couple in Joel Coen’s crackling adaptation of Shakespeare’s Scottish play.

multimedia.caption: Denzel Washington in “The Tragedy of Macbeth.” His trajectory from weary soldier to raving, self-immolating maniac is astonishing to behold.

results.title: Peter Dinklage on ‘Cyrano’ and Life After ‘Game of Thrones’
results.abstract: The actor is happy to upend 100 years of clichés by playing the romantic lead. It’s a liberating change after the series became his life.

multimedia.caption: “I was raised Irish Catholic, so I totally feel unworthy of everything,” Peter Dinklage said. “That’s what hopefully this movie is speaking to, that unworthiness we all go through.”
multimedia.copyright: Justin J Wee for The New York Times

results.title: Reliving the Pain (and Joy, Too) of My Deepest Love Onscreen
results.abstract: An author wrote about the loss of her fiancé and father of her son. When Denzel Washington stepped in to film that story, the memories flooded back.
des_facet: A Journal for Jordan: A Story of Love and Honor (Book)

multimedia.caption: The author, Dana Canedy, with her son, Jordan, and her fiancé, Charles Monroe King, in 2006.

results.title: Lucille Ball on the Big Screen, the Small Screen and Offscreen
results.abstract: “Being the Ricardos” and “Licorice Pizza” offer versions of the comedian. An author saw yet another side of her: blunt and wary of strangers but thoughtful and kind.

multimedia.caption: Nicole Kidman as the redheaded comedian in “Being the Ricardos.”

results.title: The Best Genre Movies of 2021
results.abstract: We look at the finest in sci-fi, horror, action and international films.
results.byline: By Erik Piepenburg, Devika Girish, Elisabeth Vincentelli and Robert Daniels

multimedia.caption: Park Ye-rin in “Space Sweepers.”

results.title: ‘Pig,’ ‘Val,’ ‘Adrienne’ and Other 2021 Streaming Gems
results.abstract: We put some of the year’s finest off-the-radar movies on your radar.
des_facet: Rita Moreno: Just a Girl Who Decided to Go for It (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Nicolas Cage in “Pig.”

results.title: How ‘Lord of the Rings’ Became ‘Star Wars’ for Millennial Women
results.abstract: With tender male relationships and fearless female characters, the trilogy drew in tween girls who still hold the films dear in their 20s and 30s.
des_facet: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Sam (Sean Astin), left, and Frodo (Elijah Wood) in the second “Lord of the Rings” movie, “The Two Towers.”

results.title: ‘Sing 2’ Review: Taking the Show on the Road
results.abstract: The amateur ensemble is back, this time in animal Las Vegas.

multimedia.caption: Some of the stars of the show in the movie “Sing 2.”

results.title: ‘The Velvet Queen’ Review: Searching for an Elusive Leopard
results.abstract: The documentary follows the photographer Vincent Munier and the writer Sylvain Tesson on a mission to catch a glimpse of a rare snow leopard in Tibet.

multimedia.caption: The photographer Vincent Munier and the writer Sylvain Tesson are searching for snow leopards in “The Velvet Queen.”

results.title: ‘The King’s Man’ Review: Suiting Up and Shooting Down
results.abstract: This prequel to the “Kingsman” series presents the confusing origin story of the elite British spy agency, founded by Ralph Fiennes (naturally).

multimedia.caption: Harris Dickinson, left, and Ralph Fiennes in “The King’s Man.” As the spy agency’s founder, Fiennes lends a surprising gravitas to this flibbertigibbet movie.

results.title: Sally Ann Howes, Star of ‘Chitty Chitty Bang Bang,’ Dies at 91
results.abstract: The English-born actress captivated children in the 1968 film, which became a holiday favorite. It was one of around 140 productions she appeared in during a six-decade career.

multimedia.caption: Sally Ann Howes in the 1968 movie “Chitty Chitty Bang Bang” with, from left, Dick Van Dyke, Adrian Hall and Heather Ripley.

results.title: Beyoncé Edges Closer to Her First Oscar Nomination as Shortlists Are Revealed
results.abstract: “Be Alive,” which the superstar wrote with Dixson for “King Richard,” made the academy’s cut in preliminary voting. So did Lin-Manuel Miranda, Billie Eilish and Van Morrison.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: Beyoncé at the Grammys earlier this year. Will she be at the Oscars in March?

results.title: ‘Reopening Night’ Review: The Show Goes On
results.abstract: This HBO documentary goes behind the scenes of the Public Theater’s post-shutdown, modern adaptation of “The Merry Wives of Windsor,” featuring an all-Black cast.

multimedia.caption: “Reopening Night,” directed by Rudy Valdez, documents last summer’s production of “Merry Wives” at the Delacorte Theater.

results.title: ‘Spider-Man: No Way Home’ Ensnares Audiences and Refills Studio Coffers
results.abstract: After nearly two years of lackluster box office sales for theatrical releases, Spidey breaks through to do what superheroes are supposed to do.

multimedia.caption: Tom Holland in “Spider-Man: No Way Home,” which brought in the third-highest opening weekend box-office receipts in Hollywood history.

results.title: The 1947 ‘Nightmare Alley’: A Dark View of Class as Destiny
results.abstract: With Tyrone Power in the lead, the first adaptation had to find ways to tell a story of soul sickness that wouldn’t offend censors.

multimedia.caption: Coleen Gray and Tyrone Power as carnival workers in the 1947 “Nightmare Alley.”

results.title: How Dasha Nekrasova Is Calling the Shots
results.abstract: The “Succession” star and co-host of the podcast Red Scare has directed her first feature, “The Scary of Sixty-First,” about a house once owned by Jeffrey Epstein.

multimedia.caption: Dasha Nekrasova in a scene from “The Scary of Sixty-First,” her feature directing debut.

results.title: Kevin Feige and Amy Pascal on the Future of ‘Spider-Man’ and the M.C.U.
results.abstract: The producers of “No Way Home” address questions about another trilogy, possibly putting MJ in a Spidey suit and convincing reluctant actors to reprise their roles.

multimedia.caption: The producers Amy Pascal, left, and Kevin Feige have worked on the Spider-Man franchise in various capacities since the late 1990s.
multimedia.copyright: From left: Emma McIntyre/Getty Images; Amy Sussman/Getty Images

results.title: Streaming the Year’s Best Documentaries
results.abstract: The best movies of 2021 were even better on a big screen, The Times’s co-chief film critics wrote at year’s end. But many of their top picks are available to stream — like these five documentaries.
des_facet: Summer of Soul (... Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised) (Movie)

results.title: David Arquette Spray Paints Bozo in Brooklyn
results.abstract: The “Scream” actor is on a mission to make people reconsider clowns — including himself.

multimedia.caption: “All my humor comes from me being the butt of the joke,” said Mr. Arquette, who will reprise his role in “Scream” next year.
multimedia.copyright: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

results.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include an experimental Canadian drama, an Egyptian weight-lifting documentary and a Chilean buddy comedy.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “Ste. Anne.”

results.title: Naples, a City of Contradictions, Is Once Again a Home for Cinema
results.abstract: For “The Hand of God,” the director Paolo Sorrentino has returned to his hometown, whose cultural profile has been lifted in recent years by the Elena Ferrante novels and films like “Gomorrah.”

multimedia.caption: The Naples seafront. The director Paolo Sorrentino has set his new film “The Hand of God” in his hometown.
multimedia.copyright: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

results.title: How Bradley Cooper Deceives Cate Blanchett in ‘Nightmare Alley’
results.abstract: The director Guillermo del Toro narrates a sequence from his film noir.

results.title: Elijah Wood on ‘The Lord of the Rings’ at 20 and Being Frodo to Fans Forever
results.abstract: “I’ll never be upset at being associated with those films or for them being the largest in people’s memories of who I am,” the actor says.

multimedia.caption: Elijah Wood said that if he learned one thing from playing Frodo it’s “that there’s fortitude in his outlook that makes it all possible.”

results.title: The Most Adventurous Comedy Right Now Is Also the Most Real
results.abstract: John Wilson, Eric Andre and others are drawing on unscripted encounters to elicit deeper laughs but also more vulnerable moments.
des_facet: How To With John Wilson (TV Program)
Soft Focus with Jena Friedman (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: “How To With John Wilson” uses unscripted moments to get at complicated ideas.

results.title: ‘Rust’ Investigators Obtain Search Warrant for Alec Baldwin’s Phone
results.abstract: Detectives are nearly two months into the investigation of how a live round got into a gun that discharged on a New Mexico film set, killing a cinematographer.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: The set of “Rust,” where a gun the actor Alec Baldwin was practicing with fired a live round, killing the cinematographer.

results.title: ‘President’ Review: Zimbabwe’s Struggle for Democracy
results.abstract: In a riveting new documentary, Camilla Nielsson follows the first democratic election in Zimbabwe since 1980.

multimedia.caption: Nelson Chamisa, center, is the subject of the documentary “President.”

results.title: ‘Spider-Man: No Way Home’ Review: Listen Bud, No Spoilers Here
results.abstract: In the latest installment of the “Spider-Man” series, Tom Holland faces the past and a very secure franchise future.

multimedia.caption: Come fly with me: Zendaya and Tom Holland in “Spider-Man: No Way Home.”

results.title: ‘Last Words’ Review: Cinema After the End of the World
results.abstract: In this post-apocalyptic drama, a young man meets the grizzled last guardian of a cinematic archive, played by Nick Nolte.

multimedia.caption: Kalipha Touray, left, and Nick Nolte in “Last Words.”

results.title: ‘Mother/Android’ Review: How to Protect When You’re Expecting
results.abstract: In this sci-fi thriller, a pregnant woman and her boyfriend try to outrun hordes of vengeful robots.

multimedia.caption: Chloë Grace Moretz, left, and Algee Smith in “Mother/Android.”

results.title: In His Films, Big Roles Go to Passers-by and Professionals Alike
results.abstract: Sean Baker prefers a cast with a mix of experience levels. That was never more true than on “Red Rocket,” where many of the performers had never worked on a movie.

multimedia.caption: Simon Rex and Bree Elrod in Sean Baker’s newest, “Red Rocket.”

results.title: Paolo Sorrentino Turns the Camera on His Own Life
results.abstract: When he was younger, the Italian director was “skeptical” about autobiographical movies. Ten years ago, that changed, and he started work on “The Hand of God.”

multimedia.caption: Paolo Sorrentino has been making movies for 20 years, choosing subjects like Silvio Berlusconi and the pope.
